results.title: Dirty business
results.creator_credit: Rob Grant, Ian Fowler and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A comedy in which two young men turn to burglary for easy money, but find their attempts foiled when one finds himself locked in a bathroom. Stars Jan Marnell, Simon Beattie, George Vidalis and Alethea MacGrath.

results.title: The Diode: principles and applications
results.brief_description: Explains the principles of electron flow across a gap, basic features of the diode tube, control of the electron flow in the tube, photoelectric cells, x-ray tubes, and the diode as a rectifier.

results.title: The Difference
results.brief_description: Describes emergency treatment for excessive bleeding, failure in breathing, and cardiac arrest. Details the kind of first aid a non-professional can and should perform in case of an accident or emergency until professional help is available. Explains the needs of the bring and the consequences if the brains is denied oxygen for even a short amount of time.

results.title: Dick Hickey: blacksmith
results.creator_credit: Dave Bennett, Lorne Batchelor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The blacksmith shop as a place for home-spun philosophy, where the village old-timers gather around the smithy stove to listen as the blacksmith, personified by Dick Hickey, goes about his work and shares his reflections about old times and the blacksmith’s craft.

results.title: Diastrophism: what moves mountains, what shapes the seas?
results.creator_credit: Richard Slote, Richard Lukin and Universal Education and Visual Arts
results.brief_description: Part of the “Science and the earth” series, this film provides an explanation of what scientists know about diastrophism, the forces which shape the earth’s surface. While earthquakes and volcanoes provide some information, much more is still required. Using animated maps and drawings the effects of earthquakes on the crust, mantle and core are shown. Such theories as whether the earth’s crust is floating on a sea of molten rock, whether the surface is shrinking or expanding in area, the origin of the continents and whether currents within the earth cause folding, are explored.

results.brief_description: The film is shown first with its original commentary, then with a humorous commentary added later and under a new title, “The Catch Of The Season”.

results.title: Development of the English town
results.brief_description: This film is a study of English town-planning from pre-Roman settlements to modern housing estates. The survey includes the fortification of medieval feudal towns, the dignity and elegance of the 18th century mansions, and the chaos which the industrial revolution caused for the vast majority of the population of cities. After World War 1 new ideas for housing and town-planning were formulated but much remains to be done. World War 2 brought bomb damage to hundreds of English communities.

results.title: Deterioration of water
results.brief_description: Examines the phenomenon of polluted water by looking at sources of pollution; the role of the water cycle; methods of testing for pollutants; and purification method. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Designing a set
results.creator_credit: Betty Edmonds, Robert Edmonds and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: A glimpse of the various stages of set designing for theatre productions. Beginning with rough sketches from a conference involving the designer, director, technicians and gaffers and concluding with the completion of a set. Shows some of the problems encountered during the process, stressing the need for collaboration between the director and working crew. Two set are developed, an interior and an exterior. Produced in co-operation with Dr. Maurice Gnesin, director of the Goodman Memorial Theatre.

results.title: Designed in Britain
results.creator_credit: J.B. Napier-Bell, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: An impression of British design ranging from furniture, textiles, kitchenware and fine china to buildings and towns. Skilfully edited with minimal commentary and a complementary 50’s soundtrack. Music by Ken Moule; photography by Larry Pizer; edited by Derek York.
